tit.cmt: ハイフンを追加し、Toyouke-bime としました。

sen.j: トヨウケビメは、日本神話に登場する神。
sen.e: Toyoukebime is one of the Gods from Japanese Mythology.
Toyoukebime is one of the Gods from Japanese Mythology.
Toyouke-bime is one of the gods from Japanese mythology.
sen.cmt: mythology と小文字にしました。

sen.j: 豊受大神宮（伊勢神宮外宮）に奉祀される豊受大神として知られている。
sen.e: She is known as Toyouke no Okami who is enshrined in Toyouke Dai-jingu Shrine (Outer Shrine of Ise).
She is known as Toyouke no Okami who is enshrined in Toyouke Dai-jingu Shrine (Outer Shrine of Ise).
She is known as Toyouke no Okami who is enshrined in Toyouke Dai-jingu Shrine (Outer Shrine of Ise).

sen.j: 古事記では豊宇気毘売神、日本書紀では豊受媛神と表記される。
sen.e: She is represented as Toyoukebime-no-kami (豊宇気毘売神) in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) and Toyoukehimeno kami (豊受媛神) in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).
She is represented as Toyoukebime-no-kami (豊宇気毘売神) in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) and Toyoukehimeno kami (豊受媛神) in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).
She is represented as Toyoukebime no Kami (豊宇気毘売神) in Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) and Toyoukehime no Kami (豊受媛神) in Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan).
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: 別称、豊由宇気神、大物忌神、豊岡姫、屋船豊宇気姫命、止由気大神、止与宇可乃売神、とよひるめ 等々。
sen.e: She is also called Toyuuke-no-kami, Omonoimi-no-kami, Toyooka-hime, Yafune Toyoukehime-no-mikoto, Toyuke-okami, Toyouka-no-menokami, Toyohirume etc.
She is also called Toyuuke-no-kami, Omonoimi-no-kami, Toyooka-hime, Yafune Toyoukehime-no-mikoto, Toyuke-okami, Toyouka-no-menokami, Toyohirume etc.
She is also called Toyuuke no Kami, Omonoimi no Kami, Toyooka-hime, Yafune Toyoukehime no Mikoto, Toyuke Okami, Toyouka no Menokami, Toyohirume etc.
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: 古事記ではイザナミの尿から生まれたワクムスビの子とし、天孫降臨の後、外宮の度相（わたらい）に鎮座したと記されている。
sen.e: Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) says that Toyoukebime was the child of Wakumusubi who was born of urine of Izanami (The Female Who Invites), and was enshrined at Watarai of Geku (the outer shrine) after tensonkorin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess).

Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) says that Toyoukebime was the child of Wakumusubi who was born of urine of Izanami (The Female Who Invites), and was enshrined at Watarai of Geku (the outer shrine) after tensonkorin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess).

Kojiki says that Toyouke-bime was the child of Wakumusubi who was born of urine of Izanami (The Female Who Invites), and was enshrined at Watarai of Geku (the outer shrine) after tensonkorin (the descent to earth of the grandson of the sun goddess).
sen.cmt: 古事記 既出単語のため、補足を削除しました。

sen.j: 神名の「ウケ」は食物のことで、食物・穀物を司る女神である。
sen.e: uke' in Shinmyo means a food, and she is a female god who controls a food and grain.
uke' in Shinmyo means a food, and she is a female god who controls food and grain.
The word, 'uke' in Shinmyo (name of the god) means a food, and she is a female god who controls food and grain.
sen.cmt: 神名 補足を追加しました。

sen.j: 後に、他の食物神のオオゲツヒメ・保食神などと同様に、稲荷神（ウカノミタマ）と習合し、同一視されるようになった。
sen.e: Later Toyoukebime together with other Shokumotsu-shin such as Ogetsuhime (the Food-Goddess) were syncretized with Inari-shin (the god of harvest) (Ukano-mitama), and those were thought to be identical.
Later Toyoukebime together with other Shokumotsu-shin such as Ogetsuhime (the Food-Goddess) were combined with Inari-shin (the god of harvest) (Ukano-mitama), and those were thought to be identical.

Later Toyouke-bime together with other Shokumotsu-shin such as Ogetsu-hime (the food-goddess) and Ukemochi no Kami (goddess who possesses food) were combined with Inari-shin (the god of harvest) (Ukano mitama), and those were thought to be identical.
sen.cmt: 保食神 を追加しました。

sen.j: 伊勢神宮外宮の社伝（『止由気宮儀式帳』）では、雄略天皇の夢枕に天照大神が現れ、「自分一人では食事が安らかにできないので、丹波国の比沼真奈井（ひぬまのまない）にいる御饌の神、等由気大神（とようけのおおかみ）を近くに呼び寄せなさい」と言われた。
sen.e: According to the biography of the Outer Shrine of Ise ("Toyukegu Gishikicho"),Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) appeared by the Emperor Yuryaku's bedside, and told him to bring in Toyouke-no-okami who was a Mike no Kami and lived in Hinuma-no-manai, Tanba Province because Amaterasu Omikami did not want to worry about her own food any more.
sen.cmt: 御饌の神 Mike no Kami 定訳不明一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: According to the biography of the Outer Shrine of Ise ("Toyukegu Gishikicho"),Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) appeared by the Emperor Yuryaku's bedside, and told him to bring in Toyouke-no-okami who was a Mike no Kami and lived in Hinuma-no-manai, Tanba Province because Amaterasu Omikami did not want to worry about her own food any more.

According to the biography of the Outer Shrine of Ise ("Toyukegu Gishikicho"),Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess) appeared by the Emperor Yuryaku's bedside, and told him to bring in Toyouke no Okami who was a Mike no Kami (god of foodstuffs) and lived in Hinuma-no-manai, Tanba Province because Amaterasu Omikami did not want to worry about her own food any more.
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: そのため、丹波国から伊勢国の度会に遷宮させたとされている。
sen.e: Therefore, Toyouke-no-okami was transferred from Tanba Province to Watarai, Ise Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, Toyouke-no-okami was transferred from Tanba Province to Watarai, Ise Province.
Therefore, Toyouke no Okami was transferred from Tanba Province to Watarai, Ise Province.
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: 即ち、元々は丹波の神ということになる。
sen.e: That means she was originally the God in Tanba Province.
That means she was originally the God of Tanba Province.
That means she was originally the god of Tanba Province.
sen.cmt: god 小文字にしました。

sen.j: 丹後国風土記逸文には、奈具社の縁起として次のような話が掲載されている。
sen.e: Tangono kuni Fudoki Itsubun, a lost writing of regional gazetter for Tango province carries the following story as an engi (writing about the history) of Nagu-no-yashiro Shrine:
sen.cmt: 丹後国風土記逸文 Tangono kuni Fudoki Itsubun, a lost writing of regional gazetter for Tango province 定訳不明
sen.e: Tangono kuni Fudoki Itsubun, a lost writing of regional gazetter for Tango province carries the following story as an engi (writing about the history) of Nagu-no-yashiro Shrine:
sen.cmt: " a lost writing of regional gazetter " doesn’t make sense
sen.e: Tangono kuni Fudoki Itsubun, a lost writing of regional gazetteer for Tango Province carries the following story as an engi (writing about the history) of Nagu-no-yashiro Shrine:
sen.cmt: Province と大文字にしました。

sen.j: 丹波郡比治里の比沼真奈井で天女8人が水浴をしていたが、うち1人の羽衣を老夫婦が隠してしまったので天に帰れなくなった。
sen.e: Eight heavenly maidens were bathing at Hinuma-no-manai of Hiji-no-sato, Tanba-no-kori, and one of heavenly maidens was unable to return home because an elderly couple hid Hagoromo (a feathered robe).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Eight heavenly maidens were bathing at Hinuma-no-manai of Hiji-no-sato, Tanba-no-kori, and one of the heavenly maidens was unable to return home because an elderly couple hid Hagoromo (a feathered robe).

Eight heavenly maidens were bathing at Hinuma-no-manai of Hiji-no-sato, Tanba-no-kori, and one of the heavenly maidens was unable to return home because an elderly couple hid Hagoromo (a feathered robe).

sen.j: そのためその老夫婦の家に住んでいた。
sen.e: Therefore the heavenly maiden lived in the elderly couple's house.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore the heavenly maiden lived in the elderly couple's house.
Therefore the heavenly maiden lived in the elderly couple's house.

sen.j: しかし、10年後に家を追い出されてしまい、あちこち漂泊した末に未奈具村に至ってそこに鎮まった。
sen.e: After 10 years, however, she was driven out of the house, drifted from place to place, and then settled down in Minagu-mura.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: After 10 years, however, she was driven out of the house, drifted from place to place, and then settled down in Minagu-mura.
After 10 years, however, she was driven out of the house, drifted from place to place, and then settled down in Minagu-mura.

sen.j: この天女が豊宇賀能売神（トヨウケビメ）であるという。
sen.e: This heavenly maiden is considered Toyoukebime-no-kami.
This heavenly maiden is considered to be Toyoukebime-no-kami.
This heavenly maiden is considered to be Toyoukebime no Kami.
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: 尚、摂津国風土記逸文に、 止与宇可乃売神は、丹波国に遷座する前は、摂津国稲倉山（所在不明）に居たとも記されている。
sen.e: Settsu-no kuni Fudoki Itsubun, a lost writing of regional gazetter for Settsu Province says that Toyouka-no-menokami had lived in Mt. Inakura, Settsu Province (not known where it is) before transferred to Tanba Province.

Settsu-no kuni Fudoki Itsubun, a lost writing of regional gazetter for Settsu Province says that Toyouka-no-menokami had lived in Mt. Inakura, Settsu Province (not known where it is) before transferred to Tanba Province.
sen.cmt: " a lost writing of regional gazetter " doesn’t make sense
sen.e: Settsu-no kuni Fudoki Itsubun, a lost writing of regional gazetteer for Settsu Province says that Toyouka no Menokami had lived in Mt. Inakura, Settsu Province (not known where it is) before transferred to Tanba Province.
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: また、豊受大神の荒魂（あらみたま）を祀る宮を多賀宮（高宮）という。
sen.e: A shrine where Aramitama (God's rough soul) of Toyouke no Okami is enshrined is called Takanomiya (either 多賀宮 or 高宮).
A shrine where Aramitama (God's rough soul) of Toyouke no Okami is enshrined is called Takanomiya (either 多賀宮 or 高宮).
A shrine where Aramitama (god's rough soul) of Toyouke no Okami is enshrined is called Takanomiya (either 多賀宮 or 高宮).
sen.cmt: god 小文字にしました。

sen.j: 外宮の神職である度会家行が起こした伊勢神道（度会神道）では、豊受大神は天之御中主神・国之常立神と同神であって、この世に最初に現れた始源神であるとしている。
sen.e: Ise Shinto (or Watarai Shinto) (School of Shinto thought) established by Ieyuki WATARAI who was a Shinto priest of Geku (the outer shrine) thinks that Toyouke no Okami was identical to Ame no Minakanushi no Kami or Kuninotokotachi no mikoto, and she was the first primordial god who came into the world.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Ise Shinto (or Watarai Shinto) (School of Shinto thought) established by Ieyuki WATARAI who was a Shinto priest of Geku (the outer shrine) thinks that Toyouke no Okami was identical to Ame no Minakanushi no Kami or Kuninotokotachi no mikoto, and she was the first primordial god who came into the world.

Ise Shinto (or Watarai Shinto) (School of Shinto thought) established by Ieyuki WATARAI who was a Shinto priest of Geku (the outer shrine) thinks that Toyouke no Okami was identical to Ame no Minakanushi no Kami or Kuninotokotachi no Mikoto, and she was the first primordial god who came into the world.
sen.cmt: 神名表現を統一しました。

sen.j: また、豊受大神を祀る外宮は内宮よりも立場が上であるとしている。
sen.e: Ise Shinto also thinks that Geku (outer shrine) is in higher position than Naiku (inner shrine) because the Toyouke no Okami is enshrined at Geku.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Ise Shinto also thinks that Geku (outer shrine) is in a higher position than Naiku (inner shrine) because the Toyouke no Okami is enshrined at Geku.
Ise Shinto also thinks that Geku is in a higher position than Naiku (inner shrine) because the Toyouke no Okami is enshrined at Geku.
sen.cmt: 外宮 補足を削除しました。

sen.j: また、神道五部書等の中世日本紀の成立に大きな影響を与えた『大和葛城宝山記』では、葛城から豊受大神の伝承を補強する書が出てくる。
sen.e: In "Yamatokatsuragihozan-ki" which had a great impact on establishment of Chusei Nihongi (medieval Nihongi) such as Shito Gobusho (five-volume apologia of Shinto), the document which backs up the legend of Toyouke no Okami came from Katsuragi.

In "Yamatokatsuragihozan-ki" which had a great impact on establishment of Chusei Nihongi (medieval Nihongi) such as Shito Gobusho (five-volume apologia of Shinto), the document which backs up the legend of Toyouke no Okami came from Katsuragi.

In "Yamatokatsuragihozan-ki" which had a great impact on establishment of Chusei Nihongi (medieval Nihongi) such as Shito Gobusho (five-volume apologia of Shinto), the document which backs up the legend of Toyouke no Okami came from Katsuragi.

sen.j: 雄略22年7月、丹後より、伊勢の山田へと遷宮されるのである。
sen.e: On July 478, she was transferred from Tanba Province to Yamada, Ise Province.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On July 478, she was transferred from Tanba Province to Yamada, Ise Province.
On August 478, she was transferred from Tanba Province to Yamada, Ise Province.
sen.cmt: グレゴリオ暦に修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、記紀にはそのことは記されていない。
sen.e: However, kiki (the Kojiki and Nihonshoki) does not say anything about it.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, kiki (the Kojiki and Nihonshoki) does not say anything about it.
However, kiki (the Kojiki and Nihonshoki) does not say anything about it.

sen.j: 日本書紀には、雄略22年7月に浦の嶋子（浦島太郎）が竜宮城へ出発したことが記されている。
sen.e: Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) says that On July 478, Uranoshimako (Urashimataro) left for the Palace of the Dragon King.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Nihonshoki (Chronicles of Japan) says that On July 478, Uranoshimako (Urashimataro) left for the Palace of the Dragon King.
Nihonshoki says that on August 478, Uranoshimako (Urashimataro) left for the Palace of the Dragon King.
sen.cmt: 日本書紀 既出のため、補足を削除しました。グレゴリオ暦に修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、重大な国家的な祭祀と関わる外宮祭神遷宮の事実より、架空と思われる中国風の物語を優先して記していることには大いに注目すべきである。
sen.e: It is worth noting that Nihonshoki puts the Chinese style story which is thought to be a fiction ahead of the transfer of enshrined deity to Geku which was related to an important national religious service.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is worth noting that Nihonshoki puts the Chinese style story which is thought to be a fiction ahead of the transfer of enshrined deity to Geku which was related to an important national religious service.

It is worth noting that Nihonshoki puts the Chinese style story which is thought to be a fiction ahead of the transfer of enshrined deity to Geku which was related to an important national religious service.

sen.j: それ以外にも、この地には中国風の羽衣伝承が伝えられる。
sen.e: In addition, Chinese style legends of feathered robe was told around this region.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In addition, Chinese style legends of feathered robes were told around this region.
In addition, Chinese style legends of feathered robes were told around this region.

sen.j: 豊受大神をあたかも羽衣天女姉妹の一人であるかのごとく描いていることも含め、外宮祭神の神格を変更しようとした意図が伺える。
sen.e: There is intention of trying to change the divinity of the deity enshrined in Geku including the story that makes sound as if Toyouke no Okami were one of Hagoromo heavenly maiden sisters.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: There is intent to try to change the divinity of the deity enshrined in Geku including the story that makes it sound as if Toyouke no Okami were one of the Hagoromo heavenly maiden sisters.
There is intent to try to change the divinity of the deity enshrined in Geku including the story that makes it sound as if Toyouke no Okami were one of the Hagoromo heavenly maiden sisters.

sen.j: 比沼麻奈為（ひぬまない）神社のある京丹後市峰山町には、豊受大神が丹波で稲作をはじめられた半月形の月の輪田、籾種をつけた清水戸（せいすいど）がある。
sen.e: Mineyama-cho, Tango City where Hinumanai-jinja Shrine is located has a crescent-shaped rice field called Tsukinowaden that Toyouke no Okami started rice cultivation in Tanba and a sacred fountain called Seisuido which was used to immerse rice seed.
sen.cmt: 月の輪田 Tsukinowaden 定訳不明 清水戸（せいすいど）Seisuido 定訳不明 籾種 rice seed 定訳不明
sen.e: Mineyama-cho, Tango City where Hinumanai-jinja Shrine is located has a crescent-shaped rice field called Tsukinowaden that Toyouke no Okami started rice cultivation in Tanba and a sacred fountain called Seisuido which was used to immerse rice seed.

Mineyama-cho, Tango City where Hinumanai-jinja Shrine is located has a crescent-shaped rice field called Tsukinowaden that Toyouke no Okami started rice cultivation in Tanba and a sacred fountain called Seisuido which was used to immerse rice seed.

sen.j: これがこの地が田庭と呼ばれるようになった起源とされる。
sen.e: This is considered to be the first time this region was called Taniwa (田庭).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This is considered to be the first time this region was called Taniwa (田庭).
This is considered to be the first time this region was called Taniwa (田庭).

sen.j: そして、田場、丹波へと変遷し、丹波、但馬の地名の起源であるという説がある。
sen.e: Then, there is a theory that Taniwa (田庭) was later changed to Taba (田場) and then Tanba (丹波), and this way the name of place Tanba (丹波) or Tajima (但馬) was started.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Then, there is a theory that Taniwa (田庭) was later changed to Taba (田場) and then Tanba (丹波), and this way the name of place Tanba (丹波) or Tajima (但馬) was started.
Then, there is a theory that Taniwa (田庭) was later changed to Taba (田場) and then Tanba (丹波), and this way the name of place Tanba (丹波) or Tajima (但馬) was started.

sen.j: なお、鳥取市卯垣（ぼうがき）にも古苗代、大苗代がかつてあり、そこには半月形の苗代があった。
sen.e: There was once an old and large rice nursery in Bogaki, Tottori City which had a crescent shaped rice nursery too.
There was once an old and large rice nursery in Bogaki, Tottori City which had a crescent shaped rice nursery too.
There was once an old and large rice nursery in Bogaki, Tottori City which had a crescent shaped rice nursery too.

sen.j: これは稲葉大明神が、稲作を伝授されたことが起源で、近くの稲葉神社はこの稲葉大明神を祀る。
sen.e: This originated in an event that Inaba-daimyojin initiated rice cultivation and Nearby Inaba-jinja Shrine enshrined Inaba-daimyojin.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This originated in an event where Inaba-daimyojin initiated rice cultivation and the nearby Inaba-jinja Shrine enshrined Inaba-daimyojin.
This originated in an event where Inaba-daimyojin initiated rice cultivation and the nearby Inaba-jinja Shrine enshrines Inaba-daimyojin.

sen.j: おそらく丹後の豊受大神が、当地に降臨されたことを示すものと考えられえる。
sen.e: Probably this event would represent that Toyouke no Okami descended to this region.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This event probably represents Toyouke no Okami's descent to this region.
This event probably represents Toyouke no Okami's descent to this region.

sen.j: つまり、稲葉（稲場・因幡）の地名由来は豊受大神と関連するものと言える。
sen.e: That is, it can be said the name of place Inaba (稲葉, 稲場, or 因幡)derives from those related to Toyouke no Okami.
That is, it can be said the name of the place Inaba (稲葉, 稲場, or 因幡)derives from those related to Toyouke no Okami.
That is, it can be said the name of the place Inaba (稲葉, 稲場, or 因幡)derives from those related to Toyouke no Okami.

sen.j: 月の輪田は、昭和の圃場整備で元の地から移転、縮小されてしまった。
sen.e: Tsukinowaden was moved from the original location and reduced because of farm field development conducted in the Showa era.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Tsukinowaden was moved from the original location and reduced because of farm field development conducted in the Showa era.
Tsukinowaden was moved from the original location and reduced because of farm field development conducted in the Showa period.

sen.j: しかし、その意義の高さから、近い将来元通りに復元されることが望まれる。
sen.e: In the near future, tsukinowaden is needed to be restored to its original size because of its great significance.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the near future, tsukinowaden is needed to be restored to its original size because of its great significance.
In the near future, tsukinowaden is needed to be restored to its original size because of its great significance.

sen.j: 付近の久次嶽中腹には大神の杜があり、天の真名井の跡とされる穂井の段（ほいのだん）がある。
sen.e: There is Ookami no Mori and Hoi-no-dan which is considered to be the site of Ame-no-manai about half way up the nearby Kuji-dake Mountain.
sen.cmt: 大神の杜 Ookami no Mori 定訳不明
sen.e: There is Ookami no Mori and Hoi-no-dan which is considered to be the site of Ame-no-manai about half way up the nearby Kuji-dake Mountain.
There is Okami no Mori and Hoi-no-dan which is considered to be the site of Ame-no-manai about half way up the nearby Mt. Kuji-dake.

sen.j: また、大饗石（おおみあえいし）と呼ばれる直方体のイワクラが残っており、これが神社の縁起とも言われている。
sen.e: Also rectangular parallelopiped iwakura called Omiaeishi remains, and this is considered the origin of the shrine.
Also rectangular parallelopiped iwakura called Omiaeishi remains, and this is considered the origin of the shrine.
Also rectangular parallelepiped iwakura called Omiaeishi remains, and this is considered the origin of the shrine.
sen.cmt: スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: 天橋立の真名井神社は久次嶽山頂、大饗石、比沼麻奈為神社境内、大宮賣神社を結ぶ一直線上に位置しており、関連性は濃厚であると考えられる。
sen.e: Manai-jinja Shrine in Amanohashidate is positioned linearly with the top of the Kuji-dake Mountain, Omiaeishi, the precincts of Hinumanai-jinja Shrine, and Omiyame-jinja Shrine, and it is likely to be linked.

Manai-jinja Shrine in Amanohashidate is positioned linearly with the top of the Kuji-dake Mountain, Omiaeishi, the precincts of Hinumanai-jinja Shrine, and Omiyame-jinja Shrine, and it is likely to be linked.

Manai-jinja Shrine in Amanohashidate is positioned linearly with the top of the Mt. Kuji-dake, Omiaeishi, the precincts of Hinumanai-jinja Shrine, and Omiyame-jinja Shrine, and it is likely to be linked.

sen.j: 福知山市大江町には元伊勢豊受大神社がある。
sen.e: Oe-cho, Fukuchiyama City, Kyoto Prefecture has Moto-Ise Toyuke-daijinja Shrine.
Oe-cho, Fukuchiyama City, Kyoto Prefecture has Moto-Ise Toyuke-daijinja Shrine.
Oe-cho, Fukuchiyama City, Kyoto Prefecture has Motoise Toyuke-daijinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: Motoise として統一しました。

sen.j: 元伊勢内宮より南方の船岡山に鎮座する社で、藤原氏の流れである河田氏が神職を代々継承している。
sen.e: This shrine is located in Funaokayama in the south of Motoise Naiku Shrine, and Kawada clan which was derived from the Fujiwara clan succeed its Shinto priesthood for generations.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This shrine is located in Funaokayama in the south of Motoise Naiku Shrine, and Kawada clan which was derived from the Fujiwara clan succeed its Shinto priesthood for generations.
This shrine is located in Mt. Funaoka in the south of Motoise Naiku Shrine, and Kawada clan which was derived from the Fujiwara clan succeed its Shinto priesthood for generations.

sen.j: 河田家に伝わる文書によれば、平安時代からほぼ60年に一度の遷宮が実施されてきた模様である。
sen.e: According to the documents that have been handed down in Kawada clan, the transfer seems to be done once a every 60 years or so since Heian period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: According to the documents that have been handed down in Kawada clan, the transfer seems to be done once a every 60 years or so since Heian period.

According to the documents that have been handed down in Kawada clan, sengu (transfer of a deity to a new shrine building) seems to have been carried out once a every 60 years or so since Heian period.
sen.cmt: 遷宮 とその補足を追加しました。

sen.j: その意味でかなり格の高い神社である。
sen.e: In that sense, it can be the shrine of rather high status.
In that sense, it can be a shrine of rather high status.
In that sense, it can be a shrine of rather high status.

sen.j: 崇神天皇の御世、トヨスキイリヒメが天照大神の御杖代として各地を回るときに、最初の遷座地が丹後であった。
sen.e: During the reign of Emperor Sujin, when Toyosukiiri-hime moved all over the country as a Mitsueshiro of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess), the first transferred place was Tango.
During the reign of Emperor Sujin, when Toyosukiiri-hime moved all over the country as a Mitsueshiro of Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess), the first place she transferred to was Tango.
During the reign of Emperor Sujin, when Toyosukiiri-hime moved all over the country as a Mitsueshiro (divine spirit staff) of Amaterasu Omikami, the first place she transferred to was Tango.
sen.cmt: 御杖代→divine spirit staff と補足しました。(参考：http://eos.kokugakuin.ac.jp/modules/xwords/entry.php?entryID=27）

sen.j: その比定地はいくつか存するが、元伊勢内宮を仮にその場所とすると、この豊受大神社の意味が明確となる。
sen.e: Several presumed locations exist but if Motoise Naiku Shrine is the exact place, the meaning of Toyuke-daijinja Shrine becomes clear.
Several presumed locations exist but if Motoise Naiku Shrine is the exact place, the meaning of Toyuke-daijinja Shrine becomes clear.
Several presumed locations exist but if Motoise Naiku Shrine is the exact place, the meaning of Toyuke-daijinja Shrine becomes clear.

sen.j: 即ち、トヨスキイリヒメが丹波にいったん遷座されたときに豊受大神の御神霊が現れたとするその地が、ここではないかとする説もある。
sen.e: More specifically, there is a theory that here this place may be the place where the divine spirit of Toyouke no Okami appeared when Toyosukiiri-hime was once transferred to Tango.
More specifically, there is a theory that this place may be the location where the divine spirit of Toyouke no Okami appeared when Toyosukiiri-hime was once transferred to Tango.
More specifically, there is a theory that this place may be the location where the divine spirit of Toyouke no Okami appeared when Toyosukiiri-hime was once transferred to Tango.

sen.j: 伊勢神宮外宮（三重県伊勢市）、奈具社（京都府竹野郡）、籠神社（京都府宮津市）奥宮真名井神社で主祭神とされているほか、神明神社の多くや、多くの神社の境内社で天照大神とともに祀られている。
sen.e: In The Outer Shrine of Ise (Ise City, Mie Prefecture), Nagu-no-yashiro Shrine (Takeno-gun, Kyoto Prefecture), Kono-jinja Shrine (Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture), Okumiya Manai-jinja Shrine, she is considered to be shusaijin (main enshrined deities), and also in most of Shinmei-jinja Shrines and many shrine in precincts, she is enshrined together with Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess).

In The Outer Shrine of Ise (Ise City, Mie Prefecture), Nagu-no-yashiro Shrine (Takeno-gun, Kyoto Prefecture), Kono-jinja Shrine (Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture), Okumiya Manai-jinja Shrine, she is considered to be shusaijin (main enshrined deities), and also in most of Shinmei-jinja Shrines and many shrine in precincts, she is enshrined together with Amaterasu Omikami (the Sun Goddess).

In the Outer Shrine of Ise (Ise City, Mie Prefecture), Nagu-no-yashiro Shrine (Takeno-gun, Kyoto Prefecture), Kono-jinja Shrine (Miyazu City, Kyoto Prefecture), Okumiya Manai-jinja Shrine, she is considered to be shusaijin (main enshrined deities), and also in most of Shinmei-jinja Shrines and many shrine in precincts, she is enshrined together with Amaterasu Omikami.
sen.cmt: 天照大神 既出のため、補足を削除しました。

sen.j: また、稲荷神とトヨウケビメを祀っている稲荷神社もある。
sen.e: Some Inari-jinja Shrine enshrines both Inari-shin (the god of harvest) and Toyoukebime.
Some Inari-jinja Shrine enshrine both Inari-shin (the god of harvest) and Toyoukebime.
Some Inari-jinja Shrine enshrine both Inari-shin (the god of harvest) and Toyouke-bime.
